questions.text: What is the most common route of infection in acute suppurative otitis media?
questions.solution:
The eustachian tube is the most common route of infection in acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM).

The infection travels via the lumen of the tube or along subepithelial peritubal lymphatics. It can also spread from the external ear through a traumatic perforation or via the blood but it is rare.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not predispose to eustachian tube obstruction?
questions.solution:
Choanal atresia does not predispose to eustachian tube obstruction.

Eustachian tube obstruction is caused by:

  • Extrinsic causes:
    • Adenoid hypertrophy
    • Nasopharyngeal tumors
    • Nasal pack
  • Intrinsic causes:
    • Allergic rhinitis
    • Rhinosinusitis
    • Upper respiratory tract infection
  • Defective functioning of the tube:
    • Cleft palate
    • Down syndrome
    • Submucous cleft palate

Eustachian tube obstruction can lead to complications such as:

  • Acute suppurative otitis media
  • Otitis media with effusion
  • Chronic suppurative otitis media
  • Atelectasis and ossicular necrosis

questions.text: A worried mother brings her febrile infant to the ER. He is crying incessantly and clutching his ear. He had the following finding on otoscopy. What is the most likely organism implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the image showing congested tympanic membrane with purulent effusion and absent cone of light is suggestive of acute suppurative otitis media. The most likely organism implicated is Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Organisms causing ASOM in infants and young children:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae 
  • Moraxella catarrhalis 
  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.text: Otologic examination of a febrile child with otalgia is shown below. What is the stage of acute suppurative otitis media seen here?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and image show the stage of pre-suppuration of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM). 

During this stage, due to prolonged tubal occlusion, pyogenic organisms invade the tympanic cavity. An inflammatory exudate appears in the middle ear and there is congestion of pars tensa.

A leash of blood vessels appears along with the handle of malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane imparting it a cart-wheel appearance. Later, the whole of the tympanic membrane including pars flaccida becomes uniformly red.

Symptoms of this stage include marked earache, a high degree of fever, hearing loss, and tinnitus (seen only in adults). Tuning fork tests show the conductive type of hearing loss.

questions.text: What is the most common site of perforation of the tympanic membrane in acute suppurative otitis media?
questions.solution:
The most common site of perforation of the tympanic membrane in ASOM is the posterior half of pars tensa where usually, a small perforation is seen.

Note: As per Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat 7th edition, the perforation most commonly occurs in the anteroinferior quadrant. However, as Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery; 7th Edition mentions the most common site as the posterior half of pars tensa, we have picked it as the best option in this question.

questions.text: How will you manage a patient who is diagnosed to have acute suppurative otitis media in the pre-suppuration stage?
questions.solution:
Management of ASOM in the pre-suppuration stage involves the usage of antibiotics and decongestants. 

Myringotomy is indicated only when there is an impending rupture of tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presented to the OPD with complaints of excruciating pain in the right ear, deafness and decreased sleep. On examination, she had right-sided LMN facial nerve paralysis and bulging tympanic membrane on otoscopy. Which of the following best describes the procedure to be done?

choices.text: Removal of disease and reconstruction of hearing

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) complicated by right-sided LMN facial nerve palsy. Otoscopic finding of bulging tympanic membrane is an indication to perform myringotomy i.e., surgical opening in the tympanic membrane. 

Treatment of facial nerve paralysis secondary to otitis media

  • Conservative management is preferred, using antibiotics and corticosteroids.
  • Myringotomy and a ventilation tube should be added when spontaneous perforation of the tympanic membrane has not occurred.
  • Facial nerve decompression is not usually necessary.

Tympanoplasty is the removal of disease from the middle ear and reconstruction of hearing with or without myringoplasty.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with fever and earache. On examination, the tympanic membrane appears congested and bulging with a loss of landmarks. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The scenario points towards a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM). Antibiotics form the mainstay of treatment in acute suppurative otitis media, and if the tympanic membrane is bulging, myringotomy should be done. 

Myringotomy is the procedure involving incising the tympanic membrane to evacuate pus. It is indicated when:

  • The tympanic membrane is bulging and there is acute pain.
  • There is an incomplete resolution despite antibiotics and the drum remains full with persistent conductive deafness.
  • There is persistent effusion beyond 12 weeks.

The FDA recently approved the Tula system to deliver local anesthesia directly towards the eardrum and painless placement an ear tube. This is indicated for patients six months of age and older, thus eliminating the need for general anesthesia in children for myringotomy procedures.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: You are an ENT resident assisting on a myringotomy in a patient with serous otitis media. In which quadrant would you make the incision?
questions.solution:
In serous otitis media, a radial incision is made in the anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane. 

A curvilinear incision is used in acute suppurative otitis media in the posteroinferior quadrant (smiling incision).

Note: Although an anteroinferior incision is the first step, we resort to an anterosuperior incision in the case of thick secretions that are difficult to aspirate. The 'beer-can' principle supports the said mechanism.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would you expect to observe the light-house effect?
questions.solution:
The light-house effect is seen in acute mastoiditis, which is a complication of otitis media. This effect is described as a pulsatile mucopurulent or purulent discharge, coming through a central pin-hole perforation of pars tensa. This suggests a reservoir of infection in the mastoid and middle ear.

Note: Otoscopic signs in intratympanic glomus tumors include:

  • Red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane
  • Pulsation sign or Brown sign - when ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel’s speculum, the tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with measles is brought to the OPD with complaints of profuse otorrhea. Otoscopy is suggestive of acute necrotizing otitis media. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
β-hemolytic streptococcus is the most common organism causing acute necrotizing otitis media. 

Acute necrotizing otitis media is a variety of acute suppurative otitis media. This is often seen in children suffering from measles, scarlet fever, or influenza. 

It leads to the destruction of the entire tympanic membrane, middle ear mucosa, and air cells. There is profuse otorrhoea. In such cases, healing is followed by fibrosis or ingrowth of squamous epithelium from the meatus leading to a secondary acquired cholesteatoma.

Treatment is early antibiotic therapy for at least 7- 10 days.  Cortical mastoidectomy may be indicated if medical treatment fails to control or the condition gets complicated by acute mastoiditis.

questions.text: What is glue ear also called as?
questions.solution:
Glue ear is also called secretory otitis media. It refers to otitis media with effusion.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of hearing loss in children?
questions.solution:
Otitis media with effusion, or glue ear, is the most common cause of hearing loss in children.

Clinical features of glue ear include:

  • Bilateral, painless, and fluctuating hearing loss. Conductive hearing loss not more than 40 dB is observed.
  • Defective and delayed development of speech.
  • Occasional mild earaches are present.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding serous otitis media?

choices.text: Function of the eustachian tube is abnormal in most cases
Adenoid hypertrophy is the most common cause in children causing bilateral serous otitis media
Tumors of nasopharynx is the most common cause in adults causing unilateral serous otitis media
The effusion is thick, viscid and unsterile in most cases

questions.solution:
The effusion is thick, viscid and sterile in most cases of serous otitis media.

Etiology of serous otitis media:

  • Malfunctioning of eustachian tube:
    • Adenoid hyperplasia in children - causes bilateral serous otitis media
    • Benign and malignant tumors of the nasopharynx - should always be excluded in unilateral serous otitis media in an adult
    • Cleft lip, cleft palate and chronic tonsillitis - interference with ET opening 
  • Otitic barotrauma
  • Allergy - increased middle ear secretions 
  • Unresolved ASOM - due to inadequate treatment dosage or duration
  • Viral infections - increased secretory activity due to stimulation of middle ear mucosa

questions.text: You see a child with delayed development of speech as part of a health visit in a local school. The otoscopic appearance of the ear is shown below. Hearing loss of 20 dB is detected in audiometric tests. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image suggest a diagnosis of serous otitis media. 

The golden yellow discoloration of the tympanic membrane is caused by the clear watery straw-colored effusion filling the middle ear. Since the fluid is clear, one can see the structures of the middle ear quite clearly on otoscopy.

Patients having serous otitis media will have hearing loss that rarely exceeds 40 dB. This deafness can pass unnoticed, and maybe accidentally discovered during audiometric screening tests. Because of hearing loss, the development of speech is delayed or defective.

Otoscopic findings in serous otitis media:

  • Fluid level and air bubbles are seen when fluid is thin and the tympanic membrane transparent.
  • In chronic cases, the fluid becomes very sticky. Hence, the name glue ear. 
  • The tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with a loss of light reflex.
  • The mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted.

questions.text: What type of tympanogram would you expect to see in a patient with serous otitis media?
questions.solution:
B-type tympanogram is expected in a case of serous otitis media.

Here, compliance decreases i.e., mobility of tympanic membrane is restricted due to the effusion, usually secondary to negative middle ear pressure (eustachian tube obstruction). This results in a B-type tympanogram. 

Hearing tests suggestive of conductive hearing loss as seen in serous otitis media:

  • Rinne negative (BC>AC).
  • Weber - lateralized towards the worse ear
  • Audiogram - AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
  • Impedance audiometry - flat curve (reduced compliance, shift to the negative side)

Note: Tympanograph is Flat when there is Fluid in the middle ear.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is not used to treat a patient with glue ear?
questions.solution:
Serous otitis media can be managed by cortical mastoidectomy. It is sometimes required for removing loculated thick fluid or other associated pathologies such as cholesterol granuloma. 

Management of glue ear:

  • Medical:
    • Antihistaminics
    • Decongestants
    • Antibiotics 
    • Valsalva maneuver.
  • Surgical:
    • Myringotomy and aspiration
    • Grommet insertion
    • Tympanotomy
    • Cortical mastoidectomy

A grommet is placed in the middle ear to aerate and drain the middle ear. It acts as a substitute for the blocked eustachian tube. It is placed through radial myringotomy in the anteroinferior quadrant. The device is shown in the image below:

questions.text: A child with hearing difficulty is diagnosed to have glue ear. Which of the following is not a possible sequela of this condition?
questions.solution:
Otosclerosis is not a possible sequela of glue ear. Otosclerosis is a hereditary disease of the bone of the inner ear, which mostly affects the stapes footplate area. It is not related to other ear pathologies.

The sequelae of long-standing glue ear include:

  • Atrophy of tympanic membrane (TM) and myringosclerosis (fibrosis of TM)
  • Atelectasis of middle ear - when the tympanic membrane gets retracted over the promontory
  • Ossicular necrosis
  • Tympanosclerosis - collagen deposits within the middle ear
  • Retraction pockets in TM and cholesteatoma
  • Cholesterol granulomas - due to stasis of secretions in the mastoid and middle ear

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media?
questions.solution:
Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media. It is a painless condition.

Tuberculosis of the ear is usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It occasionally spreads hematogenously, from a tubercular focus in the lungs, tonsils, and cervical or mesenteric lymph nodes

It presents as a painless condition with foul-smelling discharge from the ear, that does not respond to standard antibiotic treatment. Patients have severe hearing loss that is out of proportion to symptoms. Although predominantly conductive, sensorineural hearing loss may also occur if the labyrinth is involved.

A thickened tympanic membrane with multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft is seen. 

The image below shows the tympanic membrane in tuberculous otitis media: 

Histopathology shows submucosal tubercles with Langhans giant cells and caseous necrosis. Smears and culture of ear discharge may be positive for acid-fast bacilli (AFB). Evidence of primary pulmonary tuberculosis may also be seen on chest radiography. 

Facial nerve palsy is a common complication. Mastoiditis, postauricular fistula, and osteomyelitis are also seen.

Treatment includes aural toilet, treatment of secondary bacterial infections, and a full course of antitubercular therapy followed by reconstructive surgery.

questions.text: A 42-year-old farmer presented to your clinic after developing painless otorrhoea and hearing loss in his right ear. Examination revealed multiple perforations in the pars tensa in addition to a purulent, foul-smelling discharge with right facial nerve palsy. Audiometry indicated a 35 dB conductive hearing loss. Which of the following does not constitute an essential part of the treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem consisting of painless otorrhoea, conductive hearing loss with multiple perforations in the pars tensa, and right facial nerve palsy point to a diagnosis of tuberculous otitis media, for which corticosteroids do not form an essential part of the treatment.

Tuberculosis of the ear usually occurs secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It is occasionally blood-borne, spreading from a tubercular focus in the lungs, tonsils, cervical or mesenteric lymph nodes. Tuberculous otitis media is mostly seen in children and young adults.

It presents as a painless condition with foul-smelling discharge from the ear, that does not respond to standard antibiotic treatment. A thickened tympanic membrane with multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft is seen. 

Facial nerve palsy is the most common complication. Mastoiditis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis are also seen.

Histopathology shows submucosal tubercles with Langhans giant cells and caseation necrosis. Smears and culture of ear discharge may be positive for AFB. Chest X-ray features of tuberculosis along with other evidence of tuberculosis in the body help in confirmation of the diagnosis. DNA probe and PCR from the ear discharge can provide an early diagnosis.

Treatment includes:

  • Antitubercular therapy
  • Aural toilet
  • Treatment of secondary infection
  • Mastoid surgery for complications.

 Reconstructive middle ear surgery is delayed till antitubercular therapy has been completed.
